Explore and implement chain-based graph editing workflows
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":80,"prompt":"i want to explore some different ways of creating the graph. placing nodes and drawing edges is a great escape hatch, but it's quite labor intensive. some observations: 1. probably around 75% of an audio-graph is about chaining node's first input/output port sequentially 2. in audiochain the order of effects can determine the sound -> having a happy path for switching nodes around would be very helpful (think the ease of moving around an effect in an ableton fx chain) -> let's explore together some options for helping with this. some personal observations: 1. add fx chain node (we already sketched something out, see stashes), possible, but still a bit labor intensive, not very clear how to visualize cleanly external connections. as not all nodes can be sequentially lined up (we only consider the first port -> x/audio can be connected to audio/x and the like 2. idea i had right now: option+drag around a node -> a. move ghost version of node + on all other nodes that can be connected to either its first input/output + if connected to node they should have the same shape for input/output (so they can be interjected). there are additional handles at the left/right of the nodes -> when dragging the cursor over these handles, the ghost node is injected in the chain. c. when releasing the original node dissapears, and the ghost note becomes the actual node (including the state of the original node) -> one consideration around this is how to deal with overlapping nodes -> do you create space for the new node by moving other graph nodes around? what is the heuristic here -> let's explore other options together"}

Replace Y Layout with Column-Ordering Approach
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Plan to implement

Replace Y Layout with Column-Ordering Approach

Context

The autolayout Y-layout pipeline has accumulated 5 passes (2, 2b, 2c, 2d, 2e) where each pass patches conflicts from the previous one. The root cause: Pass 2 processes fan-out groups independently, blind to other groups in the same column. Passes 2b-2e are all fixups for this design flaw.

The fix: compute a column ordering upfront (which chain goes above which in each column), then stack from that ordering. Cross-group overlaps become impossible by construction."}

nodes.title: Design chain/row/CPM algorithm spec in AUTOFORMAT.md
How to abstract graph structure for layout
Chain + Row abstraction: chains are linear node sequences between boundary nodes; rows group top-aligned chains by x-range
Algorithm for X-position computation
CPM forward+backward pass: forward places nodes at minimum x via merge rules; backward pulls splits toward downstream merges
How to determine each node's x rule
5-rule priority hierarchy: primary root anchored, merge uses max-parent, last-internal-before-lower-merge pulls, split/secondary-root pulls toward independent merge, else sequential
Q3 resolved: row assignment is per-chain not per-node; boundary nodes starting multiple chains may land in different rows
Q5 resolved: CPM forward/backward pass supersedes memoized recursion framing
Q6 resolved: Kahn's algorithm (BFS topological sort) for forward pass; all roots are initial nodes processed simultaneously
Q7+Q13 resolved: row height = max(node heights in row), 30px uniform gap, chain Y = max occupied bottom-Y across full chain x-span + gap
Q8 resolved: cross-row alignment falls out of rule conditions; only first node in each downstream chain gets x-aligned, deeper connections accept longer diagonals
Q9+Q10+Q11+Q14 resolved: primary root anchored to user position; zero-internal chains valid; non-merge end boundaries fall through to rule 5; chain priority = start boundary node's current y
Q12+Q16 partially resolved: min_direct_path_width doesn't cross chain boundaries; independence checking DOES require traversal (skip split S when computing M.x_fwd to avoid cycles)
Q1 open: pass count/convergence  pulling a split can invalidate downstream merges, which may cascade; fixed-point iteration may be needed in worst case
Q2 open: chicken-and-egg between row assignment and x-positions  row assignment uses min widths but actual post-pull widths may differ, making pull eligibility circular
Q4+Q15 deferred: island collision resolution deferred to later version; audio graph cycles (delay nodes) assumed DAG for now
Begin implementing autoformat.ts: chain detection, row assignment, CPM X pass, Y pass
Algorithm thesis: 'prettier for graphs'  opinionated about structure (grid alignment, CPM x-positions) but deferential about ordering (user y-positions of branch-start nodes determine row priority)
Traversal strategy for combined row-assignment + x-computation
DFS traversal: at each split, sort branches by initial y of first node, traverse in order; row-claiming is first-come-first-served; row assignment and x-computation happen in one unified pass
Q2 resolved: DFS traversal eliminates chicken-and-egg  row ordering uses initial user y-positions (not computed x-ranges), so rows are stable before x is computed

Q1 resolved: single DFS always converges  independence (rule 4's condition) is precisely the property that eliminates circular dependency. Dominant path to any targeted merge does not go through the split, so M.x_fwd is settled before S is positioned.
Update AUTOFORMAT.md spec: DFS two-phase, primary root, Rule 2/3/4 clarifications

Spec updated: DFS is two-phase at splits (forward+post-order pull); primary root = most top-left; Rule 2 settles on first visit, cross-row parents excluded; Rule 3 clarified as higher-priority row (smaller index); Rule 4 target = nearest strictly higher-priority merge via multi-hop path, min_path_width includes intermediate boundaries, independence uses merge.x_excl
Rewrite autoformat.ts as proper DFS following updated spec
Committed spec overhaul: AUTOFORMAT.md updated with all clarifications
Rewrite autoformat.ts as proper DFS following updated spec

Performance optimizations for autoformat.ts
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":70,"prompt":"looking at the implementation, are there improvements that could be made? caching of certain paths maybe?"}

nodes.title: HIGH: descCache recreated per computeXExcl/applyRule4 call  same ancestor relationships recomputed O(NM) times. Fix: thread one persistent cache through applyRule4 and reconcilePass. Low effort, 30-50% gain on dense graphs.
HIGH: traceChain() re-walks same paths in assignRows, findBestRule4Pull, computeRule3Map. Fix: precompute all chains once after topology, pass lookup map. Medium effort, 20-30% gain.
HIGH: queryMaxBottomY is O(n) full linear scan per row. Fix: keep intervals sorted by xStart and break early when iv.xStart >= xEnd. Simple change, 40-60% gain in yPass for large graphs.
MEDIUM: isDescendantOf recurses per-call with overlapping paths. Fix: precompute ancestor sets for all nodes in one O(n) pass after topology, use Set.has() lookups. 10-15% gain in merge-heavy graphs.
MEDIUM: infos.get(pid)!.width called repeatedly inside maps/reduce in hot loops (forwardPass, findBestRule4Pull, reconcilePass). Fix: destructure once per loop iteration. 5-10% gain.
Thread descCache through applyRule4 and reconcilePass
Precompute all chains once with buildChainMap
Sort interval structure for early-exit in queryMaxBottomY
Precompute ancestor sets with buildAncestorSets, remove isDescendantOf
Hoist infos.get() lookups in hot loops, replace map+spread with for loops
